Earth's Processes

Plate Tectonics

Plate tectonics is the theory that describes the movement and interactions of the Earth's lithospheric plates. It drives processes such as continental drift, earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and the formation of mountain ranges and ocean basins.

Read more about this is some title

Weathering

Weathering refers to the breakdown of rocks and minerals at or near the Earth's surface due to exposure to environmental factors such as water, wind, temperature changes, and biological activity.

Read more about this is some title

Erosion & Deposition

Erosion involves the removal and transportation of weathered material by agents such as water, wind, ice, and gravity. Deposition occurs when eroded material settles out of the transporting medium and accumulates in new locations.

Read more about this is some title

Volcanism

Volcanism involves the eruption of magma from within the Earth's mantle onto the surface or into the atmosphere. It leads to the formation of new igneous rocks, volcanic landforms, and volcanic hazards such as ashfall, lava flows, and pyroclastic flows.

Read more about this is some title

Metamorphism

Metamorphism is the process by which pre-existing rocks undergo changes in mineralogy, texture, or chemical composition due to heat, pressure, or chemical alteration.

Read more about this is some title

Hydrological Cycle

The hydrological cycle involves the continuous movement of water between the Earth's surface, atmosphere, and subsurface reservoirs. It includes processes such as evaporation, condensation, precipitation, runoff, infiltration, and groundwater flow.

Read more about this is some title

Glacial Processes

Glacial processes involve the movement, erosion, and deposition of ice masses (glaciers). They shape landscapes through processes such as abrasion, plucking, moraine deposition, and glacial retreat.

Read more about this is some title

Sedimentation

Sedimentation is the process of sediment accumulation and layering, leading to the formation of sedimentary rocks through compaction and cementation.

Read more about this is some title

Diagenesis

Diagenesis refers to the physical and chemical changes that occur in sedimentary rocks after deposition but before metamorphism.

Read more about this is some title
